attributes.value: A 73-year-old engineer at the centre of a police investigation into Chinese spying fears did consultancy work for a gas turbine company in China, a source told
The Times
last night.

Bryn Jones, a former chief combustion technologist at Rolls-Royce, which builds parts for the UK’s most advanced warplanes including the F-35 Lightning II and the Eurofighter Typhoon, would travel to China as part of this work, according to the source, who knows him.

Police are focusing on whether the married father of five, who lives in Derby and is a visiting professor at a university in China, received gifts from the Chinese while in the country, security sources said. A financial motive is also being explored. It is understood that Mr Jones, who has

headline: Rolls-Royce ‘spy’ Bryn Jones was Chinese consultant
shortHeadline: Rolls-Royce spy Bryn Jones was Chinese

attributes.value: The
Trump
administration is urging Britain to contribute more towards Nato even though it already meets the alliance’s defence spending target.

The American president appears keen for his closest ally to increase expenditure above 2 per cent of GDP as part of a wider effort to make Europe contribute more towards the alliance, according to a senior source.
The White House push is being used in Whitehall to put pressure on
Philip Hammond
to increase defence spending. The chancellor is set for a showdown with Gavin Williamson, the defence secretary, next week over how to fund a blueprint for the military, two sources said.
It is understood that Mr Williamson needs Mr Hammond, a former defence secretary, to commit to a significant increase in defence

headline: Trump pressuring Britain to pay more towards Nato

attributes.value: Britain will send about 40 military personnel to join an EU-Nato mission in Bosnia and Herzegovina to help prevent Russian meddling in a presidential election in October, the defence secretary will announce today.

Gavin Williamson will tell his 28 counterparts at a meeting of Nato defence ministers in Brussels that the move will also demonstrate the important role played by the UK in European security, according to comments released in advance by the Ministry of Defence.

“This deployment demonstrates our commitment to making sure the elections in Bosnia are free and fair — and take place uninterrupted from malign external influence,” the defence secretary said before the second day of a two-day gathering at Nato headquarters. “Our armed forces are playing a leading role in

headline: British troops to protect Bosnia election from Russian meddling

attributes.value: A Tory MP and former army officer pinned an alleged racist thief to the ground after the man hurled a bottle at a shopkeeper in London.

The scuffle took place outside a 24-hour off-licence and convenience store near Westminster in the early hours of Wednesday morning as Johnny Mercer, whose constituency is in Plymouth, was returning after a night out to the hotel where he stays during the week.

Speaking last night, Mr Mercer, 36, who served three tours in Afghanistan before turning to politics, said that he did what anyone else would have done. “I just threw him on the floor and told him to stop being a prick,” he said.
The drama began when Mr Mercer entered the shop at about 2am to

shortHeadline: Tory MP Johnny Mercer swings into action

attributes.value: Afghanistan needs more British troops to help quell a resurgent Taliban, strengthened by the mistaken and premature exit of Nato-led combat forces in 2014, one of the country’s leaders has said.

Abdullah Abdullah, the Afghan government’s chief executive, said that Britain and other Nato allies needed to offer additional personnel to train and advise the 300,000-strong Afghan security and defence forces instead of leaving the United States to do most of the work.

“It is necessary yes,” Dr Abdullah, 57, said in an interview yesterday while on a trip to London when asked about the prospect of extra UK troops almost 17 years after British and US forces first deployed to the country.
The Times
revealed last month that Theresa May is considering almost doubling

headline: Afghan chief in plea for British troops

attributes.value: Christopher Steele, the former spy, has accused three Russian businessmen of intimidation in a legal fight over a dossier alleging Kremlin links to President Trump.

Lawyers for the former MI6 officer have filed two motions with a court in Washington to dismiss an attempt by Mikhail Fridman, Petr Aven and German Khan, who live in the UK, to sue Mr Steele for defamation after they were named in the Trump files.

“This case was filed to punish and intimidate,” said Christina Eikhoff, a partner at Alston and Bird, the US law firm that is representing Mr Steele and Orbis Business Intelligence, the private intelligence company that he co-owns and is also named in the litigation.
“Mr Steele is not intimidated,” Ms Eikhoff told
The Times

The Times

headline: Former spy Christopher Steele attacks Russians in Trump dossier case
shortHeadline: Former spy Christopher Steele attacks Russians

attributes.value: A British clergyman known as the Vicar of Baghdad expressed indignation and hurt last night as he revealed that he had been the subject of a counterterrorism investigation since 2016 over claims he had paid Islamic State to secure the release of sex slaves.

Canon Andrew White, 54, who was the vicar of St George’s Church in the Iraqi capital until 2014, said that he received notification from Scotland Yard only last month to say that the investigation had been dropped and that no further action would be taken.
He said if he had not been a clergyman he would have been angry at the way the police had treated him and his family. Officers had raided his home, taken away electronic devices and kept

headline: Canon Andrew White cleared of paying Isis to free sex slaves
shortHeadline: Canon Andrew White cleared of paying Isis

attributes.value: It wasn’t a Russian missile or a Chinese cyberhack that scuppered the long-awaited arrival of Britain’s newest and most expensive fast jets from the United States.
Instead, stormy conditions and rough seas kept four “all-weather” F-35 Lightning II warplanes — costing up to £150 million each — at an air base in South Carolina.
The no-show left a party of top brass and senior officials, bound for RAF Marham in Norfolk, with an “embarrassing” hole in their diaries.

“How pathetic,” one defence source said of the decision by the Royal Air Force to postpone the transatlantic flight until conditions were more favourable. “It is bonkers . . . embarrassing,” a second defence source said. “Not sure why weather should delay an all-weather fighter.”
The Ministry

headline: Bad weather delays arrival of Britain’s new F-35 warplanes
shortHeadline: Bad weather delays arrival of Britain’s new F-35s

attributes.value: People with a dodgy leg, weight problems or asthma should be able to join the military provided they have top cyberskills, the outgoing head of the armed forces believes.

Air Chief Marshal Sir Stuart Peach used his final public speech as chief of the defence staff to say that he was “quite relaxed” at the idea of troops with world-class cyberwarfare talents never deploying into harm’s way overseas and instead fighting from their keyboard in the UK.

Such servicemen and women would not be required to meet the strict medical fitness standards that the Royal Navy, army and RAF require of its recruits. “We need to be prepared to do some things that some people in the room might find uncomfortable,” Sir Stuart told an

headline: Army to relax fitness rules for ‘armchair cyberwarriors’
